docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I applaud Jacob Hacker's discussion of ''How Not to Fix Medicare'' (Op-Ed, July 2). The Bush administration has learned well how to dismantle a social program by disguising a bill with a euphemistic title and throwing in a little bait.
docs.abstract: Dr George Ubogy letter praises Jacob Hacker's July 2 Op-Ed article on high cost of Medicare bill
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I applaud Jacob Hacker's discussion of ''How Not to Fix Medicare'' (Op-Ed, July 2). The Bush administration has learned well how to dismantle a social program by disguising a bill with a euphemistic title and throwing in a little...

docs.lead_paragraph: FUNDS that focus on stocks that pay dividends were once considered as racy as an old station wagon. But they are back in fashion, and not only because President Bush's big tax cut on dividends became law in May. During the last decade, dividends were scarcely a market focal point. Investors sought growth, and companies plowed profits back into their businesses to achieve it, especially in the heady days of the late 1990's. Recently, however, investors have shown renewed interest in income-paying stocks and funds, in response to both the three-year-old bear market and the slumping yields on bonds and money market accounts.

headline.main: Mutal Funds Report; A Fresh Interest in Dividend-Paying Stocks

docs.abstract: Mutual funds specializing in dividend-paying stocks are returning to popularity as result of Bush administration's tax cut on dividends; financial advisers expect more companies to offer or boost dividends as result of favorable tax treatment, with corresponding increase in emphasis on dividends among mutual funds; Monica Noel, certified financial planner, comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: FUNDS that focus on stocks that pay dividends were once considered as racy as an old station wagon. But they are back in fashion, and not only because President Bush's big tax cut on dividends became law in May.     During the last decade, dividends...

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of big companies in Manhattan are bypassing the 911 system for their medical emergencies, and signing up instead with private ambulance services that hold out the promise -- explicitly or not -- of better, faster service. The ambulances run by these services do not answer 911 calls, responding instead only to calls from their corporate customers. The ambulance companies say their crews are less busy than those who answer 911 calls, are more likely to be close to the scene of an emergency, and are familiar with their clients' high-rise buildings -- all leading, at least in theory, to faster responses.

headline.main: Not Counting on 911, Companies Hire Private Ambulances

docs.abstract: Growing number of Manhattan companies, including The New York Times, are using private ambulance services rather than city's 911 emergency system even though crews they are not as well trained and equipped as city's Emergency Medical Services; private ambulances often affiliate with hospitals, agreeing to bring them their patients who are more likely to have medical insurance than patients picked up by EMS; cost of service ranges from $1,500 to $30,000 yearly, plus same per trip fee EMS charges, which are usually billed to insurance companies; FastCare, Emergacare and MetroCare say familiarity with clientele's buildings, and stationing ambulances near them, help them get to patients quicker, a claim that city disputes; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A growing number of big companies in Manhattan are bypassing the 911 system for their medical emergencies, and signing up instead with private ambulance services that hold out the promise -- explicitly or not -- of better, faster service.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Improving the Odds of Good Care'' (editorial, July 2) discusses the RAND study revealing what you call ''the surprising and shocking failure of the medical profession to deliver the best known care'' to Americans. You discuss solutions like performance evaluations, computerized information technology and financial incentives.

headline.main: Why Our Health Care Falls Short

docs.abstract: Dr Herber S Peyser letter responding to Jul 2 editorial on RAND study, which found inequitable reimbursement for medical treatment, argues that health care system must be reformed to reward wellness measures

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill that would impose strict limits on jury awards in medical malpractice cases -- a central element of President Bush's plan to revamp tort law -- appears headed for defeat in the Senate. But the majority leader, Bill Frist, intends to introduce the measure on Monday anyway, forcing a vote that could be used against Democrats in the next election. The bill, similar to one the House passed in March, would limit awards for pain and suffering to $250,000.

headline.main: Short of Votes, Senate G.O.P. Still Pushes Malpractice Issue

docs.abstract: Senate majority leader Bill Frist plans to offer bill to impose strict limits on jury awards in medical malpractice cases, central element of Pres Bush's plan to revamp tort law, even though bill seems headed for defeat; wants to force vote that could be used against Democrats in next election and could lead to compromise later in year; faces charges of conflict of interest because of his family's holdings in hospital chain and medical malpractice insurer; doctors, insurers and business groups are lobbying heavily for bill; opponents say $250,000 cap on pain and suffering awards is too restrictive; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A bill that would impose strict limits on jury awards in medical malpractice cases -- a central element of President Bush's plan to revamp tort law -- appears headed for defeat in the Senate. But the majority leader, Bill Frist, intends to introduce...

docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT A. OLSTEIN says he was not surprised by the recent wave of corporate accounting scandals. For nearly his entire Wall Street career, Mr. Olstein has been watchful about accounting irregularities. ''It ebbs and flows, and in a bull market, as valuations grow, so do imaginations and creativity,'' said Mr. Olstein, 61, who runs the $1.4 billion Olstein Financial Alert fund, based in Purchase, N.Y.

headline.main: Mutual Funds Report; This Manager Keeps His Focus on the Balance Sheet

docs.abstract: Profile of Robert Olstein, manager of $1.4 billion midcap blend fund Olstein Financial Alert Fund; Olstein focus is on careful scrutiny of companies' financial statements, both to avoid potential implosions and to identify rebounding companies and industries; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you wonder which Medicare prescription drug plan would work best for you or a loved one -- the version passed by the House or the one by the Senate -- a resource from the Kaiser Family Foundation may help. The foundation has a calculator at its site, www.kaisernetwork.org/drugcalculator, that provides a side-by-side comparison of a person's costs in the two versions.
docs.abstract: Online calculator at Kaiser Family Foundation web site provides comparison of projected Medicare prescription drug costs under House and Senate versions of legislation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Improving the Odds of Good Care'' (editorial, July 2), a government-sponsored national health care system is omitted from the list of possible solutions. We have lived in France this last year and had the opportunity to compare care for Type 1 diabetes. My husband has had this chronic disease for more than 35 years and complains often about the lack of quality care in the United States.

headline.main: Why Our Health Care Falls Short

docs.abstract: Mary E Duffy letter argues that government-sponsored national health care should have been included in Jul 2 editorial that listed possible solutions to poor health care system

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME fell in love with the idea as children, racing dirt bikes. Others were mesmerized by ''Easy Rider.'' The rest were smitten after their own children had already grown up. For these executives and decision makers, motorcycle riding offers a release, and, much like golf, a chance to bond and perhaps discuss business in an informal setting. Most own two or three, or more, sometimes paying as much as $40,000 for one. They even have collective nicknames, like Rolex riders or ''rubs,'' for rich urban bikers.

headline.main: Executive Life; For Button-Down Riders, One Bike Won't Do

docs.abstract: High-powered motorcycles continue to be subject of fascination with decision-makers in American business, giving lift to $19 billion-per-year motorcycle industry; many riders now own multiple bikes, which can cost as much as $40,000 each; trend is not limited to business executives, with several members of Bush administration, including Health and Human Services secretary Tommy Thompson and newly-appointed Office of Management and Budget head Joshua Bolten, being enthusiasts; sales of new motorcycles in US rose 10.2 percent to 937,000 in 2002, with Harley Davidson accounting for 22 percent; photos (M)
docs.snippet: SOME fell in love with the idea as children, racing dirt bikes. Others were mesmerized by ''Easy Rider.'' The rest were smitten after their own children had already grown up.    For these executives and decision makers, motorcycle riding offers a...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Improving the Odds of Good Care'' (editorial, July 2) laments ''a surprising and shocking failure of the medical profession.'' That study participants had failed to get the recommended treatment for their illnesses almost half the time is neither shocking nor surprising if one looks at the state of health care financing.

headline.main: Why Our Health Care Falls Short

docs.abstract: Dr Samuel D Blackman letter faults society for choosing to treat medical care like any other commercial product (Jul 2 editorial) and says quality of care will continue to suffer unless changes are made
